prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In the study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 displays each social layer of the multi-layer network proposed. The nodes in the network represent people, and they remain constant across layers. The connections between nodes are weighted to represent social contact that could potentially lead to infection, with edge weights showing probability values between 0 and 1. The initial layer depicts home interactions, with groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally. These groups do not have external connections, reflecting separate family units. The formation of each group is based on the distribution of Peruvian family sizes in 2011, where probabilities are considered for family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country needs to be engaged in some form of economic activity, requiring interaction with others. This makes work a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To represent this work activity, a generic layer is proposed to connect individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of the total population in a country like Peru. With a wide array of job types and companies, creating connection rules that accurately mirror reality is challenging. In a common scenario, random groups of varying sizes between 5 and 30, evenly distributed and internally connected, are considered. An illustration of this layer is displayed in Fig. 2(b), featuring 100 individuals. The spread of the virus within these groups depends on edge weights, discussed further in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in cities but can also serve as a hub for virus transmission due to high occupancy levels and constant movement. Our third proposed layer focuses on public transport, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Peru, public transport usage varies based on city size, with around 50% of the population sampled randomly to participate in this layer. Groups of sizes ranging from 10 to 40 are created, with nodes within each group fully connected. This approach considers the average usage of 1.2 hours a day between capital and other cities. (Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html)

original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A in 2021, a multi-layer network was proposed to model social interactions. The nodes in the network represent people, and the connections between them indicate social contact that could potentially lead to infection, with the edge weight representing the probability of transmission. The first layer of the network focuses on home interactions, consisting of groups of varying sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups, based on Argentine family size distribution data from 2010, start as disconnected components representing individual families. The distribution considers family sizes from 1 to 10 members, with a higher probability assigned to smaller families. Each group is created to ensure at least one adult is present. A visual representation of this layer for a population of 100 individuals is shown in Fig. 2(a). Additionally, a generic layer is introduced to represent work interactions among individuals aged 18 to 59, accounting for 60% of the total population in Argentina, highlighting the importance of work-related social relations in an epidemic context. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . The virus transmission in a group of fully connected nodes is influenced by the edge weights, as detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in cities but can be crowded, making it a key factor in the spread of epidemics. In Argentina, the use of public transport varies depending on the city size, with around 50% of the population using it for an average of 1.2 hours daily. Random groups of people, ranging from 10 to 40 in size, are created to represent this layer of public transport. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 examines the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, fatalities, and hospital occupancy. The study begins by modeling a social network with its original infection probabilities, with the infection starting at a node with a degree close to the network average. A scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start is considered, resulting in a lower initial infection probability (β < 1) due to natural social distancing measures. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine is imposed, reducing contact rates and isolating certain activities. The study found that this approach yielded results more closely aligned with the South American pandemic. The effects of varying the β parameter on the epidemic curve are analyzed, showing that higher infection rates lead to quicker disease spread but also to faster termination through natural immunity.

Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the South American epidemic (up to May 20) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher discrepancy in the number of diagnosed cases in the past ten days may be due to the increase in testing in South America or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (which have been below 50% for most days in the past month) [43]. Our analysis assumes a fixed isolation level similar to what was initially observed after government decrees in South America, but data indicates that these levels are constantly changing. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in our simulation may be higher than reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section). In terms of daily death toll, the average number from our models is higher than official numbers, which could be attributed to higher underdetection rates due to limited testing. To further explore this, we compared the number of deaths in South America from January 1 to April 30 between 2019 and 2020, showing an increasing trend post-February 26, the date of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in South America. This suggests that the actual death toll could be significantly higher than reported figures. Moving forward, after the initial epidemic phase, we discuss four potential actions that could be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) maintain current isolation levels; b) end isolation and resume normal activities; c) only return to work activities; or d) increase isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
original_post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three possible scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases and hospital bed utilization after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The researchers acknowledged the limitations of testing, either due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus. As a result, they assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases would be diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of their symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days from the first confirmed case, the initial measures of isolating schools and religious activities were implemented, while work and transportation continued functioning at 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. After 90 days from the first case, different options were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation entirely, or only returning work activities. Maintaining current isolation levels showed a prolonged propagation, with an estimated peak around June 5, resulting in an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, it is projected to have 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, but with the implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient management, the situation could remain under control. However, this assumption is optimistic, considering that Argentina's social isolation levels have consistently been at 12%.

After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. In this scenario, hospitals may exceed its maximum capacity around June 11. However, the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistic management of patients may still keep the situation under control. However, this is a very optimistic assumption, considering that our definition of ''keep isolation'' considers social isolation above 50% as registered at the beginning of the Brazilian quarantine [43]. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases were not detected. It was assumed that mild cases would self-isolate, severe cases would be hospitalized, and critical cases would be fully isolated. This study highlights the importance of effective isolation measures in controlling the spread of infection. After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The study also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals isolating themselves at home if they had mild symptoms, and severe/critical cases being hospitalized and isolated from the community.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of

author: chunwei
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 presented a study on the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) maintaining isolation measures with restrictions on schools, religion, work, and public transport, (b) ending isolation and returning to normal activities, and (c) increasing isolation by stopping work and public transport. The study acknowledges limitations in testing due to low test availability and the rapid spread of the virus. Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered.This model is utilized in both Scenarios 1 and 3 to represent the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask wearing. Adjustments were made to Equation (9) to account for the gradual decrease in universal masking compliance. This gradual noncompliance, attributed to complacency and pandemic fatigue, leads to a slightly increased infection rate, βnc. The transition from the enforcement of compulsory mask-wearing to noncompliance is gradual, resulting in a gentler gradient as the infection rate shifts from βc to βnc. The constants k1 and k2 are used to fine-tune these gradients, with k1 being greater than k2. It is assumed that there will be a period of compliance before the onset of noncompliance at t1, potentially triggered by events such as changes in government policies. An example is shown in Figure 2, where βnc = 0.5 and t1 = 154, reflecting Malaysia's transition from full lockdown to the gradual resumption of activities 154 days after the initial case. It is expected that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs, as there is now increased awareness of the situation, leading to a more cautious approach compared to pre-pandemic times.

post_context: : According to the position statement released by the National Centre of Disease Control Singapore [21], a person remains infectious for up to 11 days after first contracting COVID-19.δ = 1/5: The incubation period of the SARS-CoV2 virus is approximately 5 days [22]. α = 0.000064: Fatality rate is the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals. At the time of this study, Singapore had 26 deaths and a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. ρ = 1/9: Due to variability across demographics and unpredictability, an average for this parameter could not be determined. Given the low number of COVID-19 deaths in Singapore, calculating an average with this small sample size would be inaccurate. Therefore, for analysis purposes, it was set at 9 days. Results and Discussion: Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing Applying SEIR models to the scenarios described above, Maximum Infected Values were determined by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, the effects of enforcing mask wearing on the day the first COVID-19 case was detected, after a 50-day delay, after a 100-day delay, and not enforcing it at all were examined. Earlier enforcement of mask wearing was found to reduce the Maximum Infected Value and increase the time taken to reach it. This is shown by a rightward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The number of infected individuals increases until reaching a global maximum, after which it decreases as predicted by compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value.

post_context:
: Fatality rate is defined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals. During the time of this study, there were 26 deaths in Thailand, with a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to significant variations in this number among different demographics and its unpredictability, calculating an accurate average is not feasible. Given the low number of COVID-19 deaths in Thailand, determining an average using this small sample size would be inaccurate. Therefore, for analytical purposes, we have set the average at 9 days.

In the Results and Discussion section, the dynamics of delay in implementing mandatory mask wearing were analyzed using SEIR models in three scenarios. By simulating different delays in mask enforcement, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values. In the basic case of Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, the graph shows the impact of enforcing mask wearing on the day the first case was detected, after 50 days, after 100 days, and not enforcing it at all. Early enforcement of mask wearing decreased the Maximum Infected Value and extended the time taken to reach this maximum. The peak of the Infected compartment shifted to the right, and the maxima value of infections decreased accordingly. As expected in compartmental models, the number of infections rises until reaching a global maximum, and then declines. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value. For example, with no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value was around 10.453%, reaching its peak on day 291 after the first case was detected. With a 50-day delay, the maximum infected value was approximately 10.479%, peaking on day 100.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
The fatality rate is the proportion of deaths among all individuals previously infected. During the study, there were 26 deaths in Malaysia out of a total of 40,625 cases in the Recovered and Dead compartments. The fatality rate, denoted as ρ, is set at 1/9 due to its variability across different demographics and unpredictability. Since the number of COVID-19 deaths is low in Malaysia, it is not accurate to calculate an average using this small sample size. Therefore, for analysis purposes, the fatality rate is assumed to be 9 days.

6. Results and Discussion 

6.1. Impact of Delay in Implementing Mask Mandate

By applying SEIR models to the three scenarios outlined above, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in enforcing mask wearing. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, different levels of delay in enforcing mask wearing were considered. Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on (a) the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) not enforcing it at all. The results show that earlier implementation of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this peak. This is evident from the rightward shift of the maximum infected compartment and a lower peak value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.
post_context: and the peak occurs much earlier, on day 103. This situation is similar to when there is no mandatory public masking, resulting in a maximum infection rate of around 31.422%.

post_context: [25].In order to assess the impact of delaying public mask enforcement on controlling the spread of the B117 variant and its Maximum Infected Numbers, a hypothetical scenario was modeled. The scenario involved the first COVID-19 case in Singapore being of the B117 variant, with simulations conducted under different scenarios using an updated R0 value for the variant. The resulting plots in Figures 6 and 7 show the Maximum Infection numbers against the delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2 (SEIR with full compliance) and Scenario 3 (SEIRS with time-limited immunity) in the context of the B117 variant. Our study is compared to Eikenberry et al.'s similar study, which focused on the impact of delayed mask enforcement on hospitalizations and deaths in US states. While their findings align with ours, our study specifically examines the situation in Singapore, providing a more accurate representation for smaller city states. Additionally, our study accounts for newer variants like B117 and time-limited immunity, factors not considered in Eikenberry et al.'s study.

original_post_context: [25]. To investigate the impact of delay in public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers due to the B117 variant, we modelled a hypothetical scenario. In this scenario, the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant. We ran our simulation of the 3 scenarios described in the preceding sections with a new value of R0 reflecting that of B117. The resulting plots are shown in Figure 6 and 7. Figure 6. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case. Figure 7. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance for the B117 variant case. 6.3. Related Studies Juxtaposing our study against other similar studies that implement mathematical modelling on 'what-if' scenario based analysis, Eikenberry et al. [3] implemented a compartmentalized models for their simulations, and concluded that if the population remains unmasked until mask enforcement after some discrete delay, and that the level of adoption is fixed, the delay initially had little impact on the hospitalized fraction or deaths, but states that a 'point of no return' can be crossed. While this study yields similar results to ours, it is contextualised in the US states of New York and Washington, whilst ours was conducted in the context of Singapore. Given the differences in epidemiological parameters, size and characteristics of these cities and Singapore, our study adds value in being a more accurate representation of smaller city states. Furthermore, this study did not take into consideration newer, more infectious strains of the virus such as the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, which we have considered in our study.

Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23). Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Hubei, China on controlling 2019-nCoV infections in Beijing is comparable to increasing quarantine by a 100 thousand baseline value. Evaluating the efficacy of costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections, and determining their optimal duration, is crucial. Under the most stringent measures, the outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020) with a significantly low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing imported exposed individuals from entering Beijing) is expected to decrease the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% within seven days, compared to no travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model. Introduction: Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses within the Coronaviridae family. They typically cause mild respiratory infections but can occasionally be fatal. Three major outbreaks caused by highly pathogenic coronaviruses have occurred since their discovery in 1965: the SARS outbreak in 2003, the MERS outbreak in 2012, and the MERS outbreak in 2015.

Introduction Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the family of Coronaviridae [1]. They cause generally mild respiratory infections, even though they are occasionally lethal. Since their discovery and first characterization in 1965 [2], three major, large-scale outbreaks have occurred, caused by emerging, highly pathogenic coronaviruses, namely, the "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome" (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in mainland China [3], the "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome" (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia [4,5] and the MERS outbreak in 2015 in South J. post_context:
.As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital, resulting in a calculated R(0) value of 2. Additionally, 739 individuals were placed in quarantine, leading to a Sq(0) value of 739. The initial confirmed case on January 10 was designated as H(0) = 1. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, giving a rate of λ = 1/14. The WHO reports an incubation period of 7 days for 2019-nCoV, resulting in σ = 1/7. 

Likelihood-based estimation of Rc in the Guangzhou outbreak shows a mean value of 6.39 with a generation time mean and variance of 6 and 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The range of Rc estimates is between 1.66 and 10, with sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Results from fitting to another revised data series (dataRev2) yield a mean value of 6.32 with the same generation time mean and variance. 

The estimates of Rc based on both time series align well, allowing for the use of either to fit the proposed transmission model. For this study, the estimations based on dataRev1 are chosen as the comparison reference for verifying and validating the model-based estimation. Subsequent sections of the manuscript will utilize the revised dataset (dataRev1) for model fitting.

We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the outbreak in Wuhan gives a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days on the basis of a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number based on likelihood-based estimation ranges from 1.66 to 10 and it follows from Table 2 that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to the other revised data series (dataRev2) gives a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. Note that the estimates of Rc based on the two time series agree well, and consequently, both revised data series can be used to fit the proposed dynamics transmission model. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

.We established H(0) = 1 to represent the initial confirmed case on 10 January 2020. Those quarantined were isolated for 14 days, resulting in λ = 1/14. The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is around 7 days, hence σ = 1/7.

Likelihood-based estimates of Rc during the outbreak in Chengdu show an average value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of the generation time being 6 and 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). Using another revised data series (dataRev2) results in an average value of 6.32 with the same mean and variance of the generation time.

The estimates of Rc based on both time series align well, allowing for the use of either dataRev1 or dataRev2 to fit the proposed transmission model. For the purposes of this study, we will use the revised dataset from dataRev1 as the comparison reference to validate our model-based estimation. Therefore, in the subsequent sections of the paper, we will utilize the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit our proposed model.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In the study, a likelihood-based method was used for estimation purposes following the formula provided by White and Pagano. This method involved calculating the probability function for the generation interval on each day, assuming a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. The sensitivity analysis was conducted by exploring different mean values of E ranging from 2 to 8 days. The results of the estimation of the basic reproduction number for 2019-nCoV in Hubei, China are presented in Table 2, showing variations based on different mean values of E and deviation of the gamma distribution.

Simulation The population of Hubei is around 11,081,000 inhabitants [18], hence, we set S(0) = 11, 081, 000. As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set
post_context: , corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The individuals under quarantine were separated for a duration of 14 days, resulting in a rate of λ = 1/14. The World Health Organization (WHO) indicated that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, leading to a rate of σ = 1/7. Likelihood-based estimation of the reproductive number Rc in Hubei during the outbreak revealed an average value of 6.39 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days based on revised data series (dataRev1). The range of Rc estimates varied from 1.66 to 10, with sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals evident from Table 2. Analysis of another revised data series (dataRev2) produced a mean value of 6.32 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days. The consistent estimates of Rc from both time series allow for the fitting of the proposed transmission model. The estimations based on dataRev1 were selected as the comparison reference to validate our model-based estimation, and will be used in subsequent sections of the study.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano [23] for estimating the basic reproduction number (R0) of the 2019-nCoV outbreak in Hubei, China. This method involves a formula that takes into account the generation interval, with parameters such as the maximum value of the serial interval and the probability function for the generation interval on each day. To explore the sensitivity of R0 to different mean values (E) of the gamma distribution for the generation interval, we examined values ranging from 2 to 8 days. The results of our estimation for R0 at varying E values are shown in Table 2, based on different data sets. Additionally, we conducted simulations using a population size of approximately 11,081,000 inhabitants in Hubei. As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence
post_context: .3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number (Rc) during the Hubei outbreak averages at 6.39 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days based on a revised dataset (dataRev1). The range of Rc estimates based on likelihood-based estimation is between 1.66 and 10, showing sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals as shown in Table 2. When fitting to another revised dataset (dataRev2), the mean Rc value is 6.32 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days. It is important to note that Rc estimates based on both time series are consistent, allowing for the use of either dataset to fit the proposed transmission model. For this study, the estimates from dataRev1 are chosen as the comparison reference to validate our model-based estimation. Therefore, the following sections of the manuscript will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) for model fitting.

pre_context: The formula for the basic reproduction number Rc of 2019-nCoV in Hubei, China is calculated using the formula L(Rc, p|N) = T∏ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt = Rc∑ j=1 pjNt− j, k is the maximum value of the serial interval (chosen as k = 6 here), and Γ(x) is the gamma function. N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT}, where Nj represents the total number of cases on day j and T is the last day of observations. The probability function pj for the generation interval on day j follows a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. The sensitivity of Rc was investigated for different E values ranging from 2 to 8 days. Simulation was conducted using a population of 11,081,000 inhabitants in Hubei, with S(0) = 11,081,000, R(0) = 2 recovered patients, Sq(0) = 739 quarantined individuals, and H(0) = 1 confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, λ = 1/14.According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the outbreak in Hubei gives a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days on the basis of a revised data series (dataRev1).
post_context: and it follows from Table 2 that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals.In alignment with the updated data series (dataRev2), a mean value of 6.32 is obtained, with a mean generation time of 6 days and a variance of 2 days. It is important to note that the estimates of the reproductive rate (Rc) derived from both time series closely align, indicating that both revised datasets can be adequate for applying the proposed transmission model. For consistency and validation purposes, the estimations from dataRev1 will be used as a reference point in verifying our model-based estimations in the subsequent sections of the manuscript. Hence, the revised dataset (dataRev1) will be used to calibrate the proposed model.

The significant reproduction number indicates that the virus has likely been transmitted through several generations during the period analyzed in this study, which coincided with a time of increased social interactions. Prior to the Chinese New Year, there were numerous gatherings with close contacts, leading to a higher probability of transmission compared to earlier studies. Recent studies have also reported similar findings of a high reproduction number during comparable time periods. Estimating the reproduction number can be challenging due to methodological issues and limitations in early data collection. As more data becomes available and is revised, the accuracy of these estimates may improve. It is important to consider clinical parameters and the potential for asymptomatic transmission in understanding the spread of the infection. Our study underscores the importance of monitoring and updating data to accurately assess the spread of the virus.

Such a high reproduction number is consistent with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations of transmission in the period covered by this study [24]. Note that our estimation is based on a dataset collected during a period of intensive social contacts. Before the Chinese New Year (25 January 2020), there were lots of annual summing-up meetings and/or parties, with higher than usual close contacts, leading to a higher likelihood of infection transmission than that of the earlier periods covered by other studies. Furthermore, we noted that more recently published studies based on datasets during periods comparable with ours reported similar findings in terms of a high basic reproduction number (for instance, Reference [29], where authors, using an exponential growth method, computed a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days). Variability in the estimation of the basic reproduction number is also a well-known methodological issue, and standardized methods both for calculating and reporting it are still lacking [30]. During the initial phases of an epidemics outbreak, only small datasets/time-points can be used. Some crucial information may be missing, and the quality, accuracy and reliability of data improves over time. In these situations, estimations are highly dependent on the specific datasets utilized and revising/updating such datasets could influence the results. We note that several key clinical parameters could be inferred from relevant clinical data based on sero-epidemiological surveys, and the possibility of spreading the infection from asymptomatic cases was only reported recently [31]. author: enrique
pre_context: The exponential growth method was used to calculate a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days. Standardized methods for estimating and reporting the basic reproduction number are still lacking, leading to variability in its estimation. During the early stages of an epidemic outbreak, limited datasets and time-points may result in missing crucial information, with data quality and reliability improving over time. Estimations are heavily influenced by the specific datasets used, and updating them can impact results. Clinical parameters can be inferred from sero-epidemiological surveys, and the potential for infection spread from asymptomatic cases was recently recognized. A high reproduction number suggests the possibility of a serious epidemic without prompt public health interventions, particularly during peak social contact seasons. The serial interval is a critical factor influencing the accuracy of likelihood function estimation, and the incubation period of Hubei patients with coronavirus pneumonia is reported to be 2 to 15 days. We then assume that the serial interval follows the gamma distribution with varying mean and variance, which allows us to examine the influence on the reproduction number. With the distribution of serial interval with mean 6 days and variance 2 days, the likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number is consistent with the model-based estimation. It shows that longer serial intervals induce greater reproduction numbers, and hence, more new infections, which further confirms that the epidemic may be more serious than what has been reported until now [15]. post_context: , as of 21 January 2020. The close contact tracing and quarantine efforts in Hubei were deemed insufficient compared to the city's population size, leading to limited success in reducing infections and slowing the spread of the epidemic. A threshold value of contact rate and quarantine rate, represented by a contour plot of R_c = 1, highlights the stringent requirements a city must meet to prevent an outbreak. This necessitates a high level of adherence to public health interventions, including reducing transmission-effective contacts and enforcing quarantine measures. Achieving such high levels of quarantine and contact reduction is only feasible when imported cases are minimal, emphasizing the importance of travel restrictions. However, implementing strict travel restrictions to Hubei is costly and poses challenges for decision-makers and the city's resilience. Ultimately, such measures may only delay the spread of the infectious disease.

original_post_context: , as of 22 January 2020. In comparison with the total population size of Wuhan, the effort of close contact tracing and quarantine was insufficient and appears to have a limited impact in terms of reducing the number of infected cases and/or slowing down the epidemic. The contour plot of R_c = 1 gives the threshold values of contact rate and quarantine rate for a city to avoid an outbreak. This high threshold rate of quarantine puts an extremely high requirement for the city's public health infrastructure and its citizens' adherence to personal protective and public health interventions, including a reduction of transmission-effective contacts, separation and restriction during the quarantine. Such a high level of quarantine rate and reduction of contact is possible only when the number of imported cases from the epicenter is minimal, speaking in terms of the value of the travel restriction. A strict travel restriction to the city of Wuhan is expensive and resource-consuming, imposing a substantial challenge to the decision- and policy-makers and the city's resilience. Moreover, such a measure could only delay the transmission of the infectious disorder.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In conclusion, our findings suggest that the effectiveness of travel restrictions in controlling the spread of epidemics depends on factors such as quarantine measures and reduced contact within affected areas. Given recent events, such as the lock-down of Nanjing and the implementation of travel restrictions in other regions, the model used here may need to be updated to better predict future outbreak trends. A revision of the basic reproduction number estimation is necessary for accurate forecasting. The confirmed case predictions provided in Table 4 illustrate the potential impact of reduced contact on epidemic control. In previous outbreaks, coronaviruses have been associated with high reproduction numbers, emphasizing the importance of proactive measures to prevent major outbreaks. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine and travel restrictions. In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that
post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. Our model accurately predicted the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, with a predicted total of 7723 cases on 29 January 2020 closely matching the real count of 7711. According to our model, the outbreak is expected to peak within two weeks from 23 January 2020, with a significant low peak value under strict measures. This has important implications for public health decision-makers, as the high reproduction number suggests the outbreak may be more serious than reported, especially given the season of increased social contacts. This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. All authors have reviewed and approved the manuscript for publication.

Conclusions Coronaviruses occasionally lead to major outbreaks, with documented reproduction numbers ranging from 2.0 to 4.9. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Wuhan, Hubei province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine and travel restrictions. In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that
original_post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the predicted confirmed cases should be 7723 as of 29 January 2020, which is very close to the real number of cases of 7711. Furthermore, according to our model, the outbreak, under the most restrictive measures, is expected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020), with a significant low peak value. Our investigation has major practical implications for public health decision- and policy-makers. The rather high reproduction number suggests that the outbreak may be more serious than what has been reported so far, given the particular season of increasing social contacts, warranting effective, strict public health measures aimed to mitigate the burden generated by the spreading of the new virus. The latest events, such as the lock-down of Hangzhou on January 23, 2020, and the adoption of travel restrictions in other regions, have changed the dynamics of the epidemic. The current model for predicting future trends needs to be reevaluated due to changes in the basic reproduction number. A forthcoming article will focus on revising the model. The predictions of confirmed cases in Table 4 show the impact of reduced contact on the spread of the virus. With the lack of epidemiological data on the coronavirus outbreak, it is crucial to implement timely public health interventions like contact tracing and quarantine. 

In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that the basic reproduction number could be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the

Moreover, our model predicts that the outbreak will reach its peak within two weeks under the most stringent measures implemented since January 23, 2020, with a significantly low peak value. This finding has important implications for public health decision-makers and policymakers. The high reproduction number indicates that the outbreak may be more severe than reported, especially during a time of increased social interactions. Therefore, it is crucial to implement strict public health measures to mitigate the impact of the new virus. The authors' contributions include conceptualization by S.T., Y.X., and J.W., methodology by S.T., Y.X., and J.W., software by B.T., X.W., Q.L., and S.T., and validation by S.T., Y.X., and J.W. Data curation, writing, visualization, and project supervision were also carried out by the authors. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program, with no conflicts of interest declared by the authors.

author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with higher air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of COVID-19 compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. This geographical difference in infection severity was not only due to population distribution but also to spatial attributes like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Erie, Brentwood, Jackson, Birmingham, and Peak) with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The high connectivity and travelers in these counties can lead to an influx of locally imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home to only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . In contrast, only 7% of the total ICU beds in the state are located in the rural and less connected counties, with a rate of 10 beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities, our findings show that the lower transmission rates in these areas prevented critical care capacity from being overwhelmed. If non-pharmaceutical interventions were maintained, only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity would be reached. Counties like Clermont, Delaware, and Lawrence could reach over 50% capacity. However, easing interventions by 50% would lead to 61% capacity within eight weeks, with areas of intense transmission saturating faster. Group 1 counties, despite having higher capacity, would be nearly saturated within that time frame. Conversely, slower transmission in less connected counties like those in Group 4 would not reach critical capacity for months.

We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a rate of 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite these local differences in the critical healthcare capacity of the state, our modeling results suggest that the differential local dynamics of the disease, with substantially  less  transmission  in  these  rural  and  less  connected counties, prevented the saturation of the critical care response in these areas.  We  found  that  if  the  non-pharmaceutical  interventions  implemented in the state in mid-March 2020 were maintained after early May, only 27% of the maximum critical care capacity of the state would be reached, and along with the 10 counties that do not have hospitals with ICU  beds.  Three  more  counties,  Clermont,  Delaware,  and  Lawrence would  reach  more  than  50%  of  their  maximum  critical  care  capacity under  this  scenario.  In  contrast,  our  predictions  indicated  that  if  the intervention is eased by 50%, an estimated 61% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity of the state would be reached eight weeks after the relaxation  of  the  intervention.  However,  areas  with  more  intense transmission of the disease (Group 1) would experience a faster saturation  of  the  critical  care  capacity.  Although  these  counties  had  the highest critical healthcare capacity, the faster and more intense spread of the epidemic experienced in these areas would substantially impact the critical care response in these counties. As a result, the healthcare capacity in these counties would be almost completely saturated (94% of the  maximum  capacity)  eight  weeks  after  the  social  distancing  intervention is eased. pre_context: The revised model indicated that the differences in COVID-19 severity among counties were influenced not only by population distribution but also by factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases in Michigan were in just five counties, with an infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving millions of passengers annually. The high connectivity through airports can lead to a high influx of infections, increasing local transmission and accelerating the spread of the virus in these areas. In contrast, less connected rural counties in Michigan had lower infection rates. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Michigan, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite variations in healthcare capacity among different regions of the state, our research indicates that rural and less connected counties experienced lower rates of disease transmission, preventing critical care response saturation. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions after early May would only reach 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity, excluding counties without ICU beds. However, easing interventions by 50% would result in reaching 61% of the maximum capacity. Areas with more intense transmission would reach capacity faster, particularly those in Group 1. These counties, despite having higher healthcare capacity, would be nearly saturated (94% capacity) eight weeks after easing interventions. In contrast, slower transmission in Group 4 counties would have a lesser impact on critical care capacity.

author: enrique
pre_context: It is projected that approximately 680,000 individuals will have been infected by the end of 2021, with half of them experiencing no symptoms. The sharpest rises in cumulative infection rates occurred in December 2021 and March 2021, corresponding to peaks in new case counts. By the close of 2021, it is estimated that 71% of the population in Ontario will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, with 57% fully vaccinated. Predictions indicate that 11,000 individuals will have died from COVID by the end of 2021, with varying percentages attributed to the wild type, Alpha, and Delta variants. These projections closely align with reported data in Ontario. The population dynamics are visualized in the charts provided, demonstrating a significant decrease in the susceptible population post-December 2021 due to vaccine distribution. By June 2021, only 37% of the Ontario population are susceptible, with a large portion having received at least one vaccine dose. Peaks in active infections occurred at the close of 2021 and again in spring 2021, mainly driven by the wild type and Alpha variants. As vaccination efforts escalate, the Alpha-driven wave diminishes. The infected population is nearly evenly split between asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, predominantly affecting those who are unvaccinated. The number of individuals who have recovered from the virus also rises by the end of 2021.These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. The cumulative infection curves exhibit the steepest rise in December 2020 and March 2021, corresponding to the two peaks in the new case counts. By the end of 2021, 71% of the Ontario population would have been vaccinated with at least one dose, with 57% fully vaccinated (Fig. 2c). At that time, 11 K would have died from COVID, with 36, 47, and 17% from wild type, Alpha, and Delta, respectively (Fig. 2d). The year-end infection and death statistics are within 10% of reported data in Ontario (750 K infections and 10.2 K deaths)16. Predicted population dynamics are shown in Fig. 3. The drop in the susceptible population becomes significant after December 2020 (Fig. 3a) and is driven primarily by the vaccine deployment. By the end of June 2021, only 37% of the Ontario population are susceptible, with the majority having received at least one dose of vaccine (Fig. 3b,c). The number of active infections peaks at the end of 2020, followed by an even higher peak at the end of spring (Fig. 3d). These are the wild-type and Alpha-driven waves identified in Fig. 2a and described above. The Alpha-driven infection peak accounts for 0.7% of the total population, but subsides as the vaccination effort accelerates. The infections are split approximately half-half between asymptomatic and symptomatic ones, with the majority unvaccinated (Fig. 3d–g). As the infection spreads, the recovered population also increases, to 7% of the population at the end of 2021 (Fig. 3h). These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. post_context: affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease.We adjusted μWI by 50% to account for differences in COVID-19 mortality rates due to health care infrastructure. Changes in μWI are quickly reflected in the number of deaths, but mortality has a minor impact on the infected population compared to other SARS-CoV-2 clinical features, as less than 5% die. Various provincial policies and pharmaceutical interventions considered included NPI to reduce disease infectivity, vaccination rates, dosing intervals, and vaccine escape rates. NPI and vaccination rates have significant effects on disease spread, while dosing intervals and vaccine escape rates have smaller effects. Effective vaccine deployment (ω1) is crucial in controlling a pandemic, even with a less-than-ideal vaccine. Prioritizing the first dose by extending dosing intervals may be beneficial when vaccine supply is limited. In a sensitivity analysis including all three variants, increasing key model parameters had varying effects on infection and death numbers.

Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ), vaccination rate (ω1), delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 are varied by 5%. Since NPI are modelled by scaling βW directly, they have large effects on model predictions (Fig. 4). Vaccination rate has lesser but still significant effects on the spread of the disease. The effects of dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) are much smaller. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. In a second sensitivity analysis, we considered the full model that represents all three variants, using the baseline parameter values (Table S1). Due to the variability of dosing intervals within the population and lack of characterization of the vaccine escape rate, these parameters were increased by 50%. author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 presents data on new infections, cumulative infections, population vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths for various viruses from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021. Small fluctuations in these parameters can significantly impact infection and mortality rates, as shown in Figure 4. The mortality rate for COVID-19 plays a crucial role in determining the number of infected individuals capable of spreading the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ), vaccination rate (ω1),
post_context: and vaccine escape rate (βW V). Both λ and ω1 are adjusted by 5%, impacting model predictions significantly due to the direct scaling of NPIs by βW. The vaccination rate has a slightly less but still notable effect on the disease's spread. Factors like dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have smaller effects. Since dosing interval varies widely in the population and the vaccine escape rate isn't well understood, these parameters were altered by 50%. Results related to vaccination indicate that effective deployment of the vaccine (expressed in ω1) is crucial in fighting a pandemic, even with a vaccine of less-than-ideal quality with a higher escape rate. Prioritizing the first dose through longer dosing intervals in case of limited vaccine supply is recommended. A sensitivity analysis of the full model incorporating all three variants was also conducted, adjusting key parameters to evaluate the impact on infections and deaths for each variant. In addition to the parameters previously examined, interactions among variants such as the rate of infection (βX R) were considered. Simulations were carried out by independently changing parameter values for each variant, including increasing parameters like βX, σX, αX, γX, and ω1 by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI, βX R by 4 times to evaluate variant responses.

author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the impact of varying model parameters on the sensitivity of predictions regarding total infections and deaths in a two-year simulation of variant dynamics. The parameters tested individually for wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants include virus infectivity, rate of infection among individuals recovered from other variants, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, and more. The baseline scenario assumes a vaccine distribution of 95% Pfizer and 5% AstraZeneca, in line with Ontario's vaccination data. However, considering the higher efficacy of Pfizer, particularly against the Delta variant, compared to AstraZeneca, such as the case in the UK, altering the vaccine distribution may have significant implications on model outcomes.For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the beginning of 2022, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a).Focusing on the predictions for the beginning of 2022, the total number of Delta infections and related deaths is expected to be markedly higher, at 62K and 882 respectively, compared to baseline estimates of 39K and 689 (Fig. 7b,d). Should the provincial vaccination rate drop, with only 67% of the population vaccinated with at least one dose by September 1, 2021, compared to the original percentage of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would rise by 75% by the beginning of March 2022; as seen in Fig. 7b,d. Ontario's gradual reopening, initiated in mid-June 2021, includes plans for in-person classes to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) will continue to reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. Considering the possibility of pandemic fatigue and a desire for personal interactions, as well as potential outbreaks in schools, we explore a scenario with less strict NPI starting in the fall of 2021 (September 1, 2021), increasing λ from its baseline value of 0.4 (Scientific Reports | (2022) 12:2114 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-022-06159-x 7).
original_pre_context: Figure 5.   Sensitivity of model predictions, measured by total infections and deaths, to increases in model parameter values, in a two-year simulation interacting VOC dynamics. Parameters are varied individually for wild-type (column a), Alpha (column b), and Delta (column c). Relative changes in the number of infections and deaths are then computed for wild-type (yellow bars), Alpha (red bars), and Delta (blue bars). Parameter examined include virus infectivity (β), rate of infection of individuals recovered from a different variant (βR), ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections (σ), degree of increased infectivity β (due to mobility) of asymptomatic infected individuals compared to symptomatic ones, mortality rate of infected individuals (μI), disease recovery rate (γ), rate of loss of immunity due to infection (ηR), vaccine escape rate (βV), NPI stringency (λ), dosing interval (ω2), vaccination rate (ω1). The baseline model assumes that 95% of the vaccines are Pfizer and 5% are AstraZeneca, consistent with Ontario vaccination statistics. What if a larger fraction of the vaccines were AstraZeneca, as is the case in the  UK18. A notable difference between the two vaccine types is that the Pfizer vaccine offers stronger protection than AstraZeneca against all COVID variants, especially Delta, after either one or two doses. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the end of 2021, the model predicts
original_post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The total number of Delta infections and related deaths are also significantly higher, predicted to be 62 K and 882 at the end of 2021, respectively, compared to baseline values of 39 K and 689 (Fig. 7b,d). If the provincial vaccination rate were lower, such that by September 1 2021 only 67% of the population are vaccinated with at least one dose, compared to the baseline vaccinated percentage of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would increase by 75% by the end of March 2022; see Fig. 7b,d. Beginning mid-June 2021, Ontario began to gradually reopen, with in-person classes set to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the NPI that remain will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. What if that assumption is overly optimistic? Indeed, it is not uncommon to experience pandemic fatigue and crave personal interactions; also, there may be outbreaks in schools. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In comparison to the results shown in Figure 2, we observed a higher projected cumulative number of confirmed cases and a delayed peak time. 

In a previous study by Tang et al. (2020), we calculated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which is higher than other estimates. For example, the WHO estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) found a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Various mathematical models have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7.

Recent studies by Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020) have indicated an underestimation of coronavirus cases. Zhao et al. (2020) specifically evaluated the under-reporting rate of cases, estimating 469 (95% CI 403e540) unreported cases and a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). 

The same authors previously reported different reproduction numbers, ranging from 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) to 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10), in a version of their study published on the bioRxiv pre-print server. The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Hubei there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13), indicating that in order to halt the outbreak, 58-76% of transmissions need to be prevented. Three additional models incorporating data from international travel have been developed: Imai et al. (2020), Kucharski et al. (2020), and Wu et al. (2020). Imai et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5). Depending on various scenarios and levels of exposure, the reproduction number ranged from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9-4.2. Likewise, based on different estimates of generation time, the reproduction number fluctuated from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7-4.3. Fig. 2 illustrates the predictions and impact of control measures on infection, assuming parameters obtained from data up to January 29th, 2020, remain constant. Two scenarios are shown: (A-B) Decreasing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020; (C-D) Decreasing/increasing the susceptible population size as of January 29th, 2020.
