Discussion In our previous article (Tang et al., 2020), we had estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which represents a higher value than those so far computed. For instance, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, Li and colleagues (Li et al., 2020) have computed a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9), while in several other mathematical models which have been so far devised and released as pre-prints or undergone peer-review and published, the reproduction number varies from 1.3 to 4.7. Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. Authors computed the number of under-reported coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540). Based on this estimate, the basic reproduction number was found to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
original_post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Wuhan there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The basic reproduction number was computed to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39e4.13). In terms of public health implications, in order to stop the outbreak, at least 58e76% of transmissions should be blocked. There are three further models incorporating data from international travels: the models of Imai and coauthors (Imai et al., 2020), of Kucharski et al. (Kucharski et al., 2020) and of Wu and collaborators (Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). In particular, Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5e3.5). Some studies have suggested an underestimation of coronavirus cases, such as those by Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020). Zhao et al. (2020) used a mathematical model to estimate that there may be 469 (95% CI 403e540) underreported coronavirus cases, resulting in a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). pre_context: Figure 3 shows the model's best fit to the data on cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to February 1st, 2020. The projected numbers of infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed cases are depicted. The reproduction number, which indicates infectiousness, ranged from 1.6 to 2.9. It was suggested that the novel virus would likely result in more mild-to-moderate cases compared to the SARS virus, with an estimated reproduction number of 2.0 (with an uncertainty range of 1.4 to 2.3). According to the authors, public health interventions blocking more than 60% of transmission would be crucial in controlling and containing the coronavirus outbreak. Various studies have focused on estimating the reproduction number and the effectiveness of different intervention strategies. For example, Yu (2020) calculated a basic reproduction number of 3.5 and suggested that a quarantine rate of over 90% of the infectious population would be necessary to effectively control the outbreak. Kucharski and colleagues (2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model using the Euler-Maruyama algorithm with a 6-hour time step. They estimated a time-varying reproduction number using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach and utilized multiple datasets to provide real-time estimates, taking into account the unreliability of some data sources and using Poisson probability calculations.Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. The basic reproduction number was calculated to decrease over time. Based on these estimates, the outbreak is projected to decrease significantly within a specific timeframe. Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemics outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 [95% CI 75e80] days from its beginning. Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Effective control and containment of the coronavirus outbreak relies heavily on the percentage of transmission. According to research by Yu (2020), a quarantine rate of over 90% of the infectious population is necessary to successfully manage the spread of the virus, as determined through a basic reproduction number of 3.5. Kucharski and his team (Kucharski et al., 2020) utilized a stochastic SEIR model with a 6-hour time-step and a transmission rate following a geometric Brownian motion to estimate the time-varying reproduction number. By combining various datasets and employing the Poisson probability calculation, they were able to provide real-time estimates of transmission dynamics, emphasizing the fluctuating and random nature of transmission over time. Similar to previous studies, the risk of transmission and outbreak size were modeled based on specific distributions, with a median reproduction number fluctuating between 1.6 and 2.9 prior to travel restrictions being implemented.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). It was also discovered that a one-day decrease in the time between illness/symptom onset and isolation could reduce peak population size by 72-84% and the overall number of infected cases and deaths by 68-80%. Various studies have used different models to estimate the reproduction number, with values ranging from 2.0 to 3.1. The estimated time of the most recent common ancestor of the virus was December 17th, 2019. Differences in findings among studies may be due to methodological variations such as model assumptions, parameters, and dataset choices. The reproduction number has been observed to fluctuate over time, reflecting the changing dynamics of virus transmission and case reporting.

As the total population size remains constant, the local stability of the model can be assessed through the remaining coupled system of state variables. The coefficients of the characteristic polynomial can be rewritten to verify these conditions.

text: the  total  human  population  size  at  time  t  denoted  as N(t)
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili and colleaguesBMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352 Page 2 of 5 non-linear  interactions  between  humans  and  the  environment;  and  (3)  thorough  simulation  studies  were performed. Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, we have N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has shown that the COVID-19 virus can spread in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to human. Both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) individuals infected with the virus can transmit it to susceptible individuals S(t) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking precautions, the virus can spread to the environment. Since the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for several days, individuals in close contact with the environment are at risk of exposure, particularly in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are put in place. The susceptible individual initially moves to the exposed population E(t) as there is an incubation period. The exposed individual then transitions to either the asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infectious population. P(t) represents the amount of pathogens present during human interaction at time t. Most infectious individuals recover and move to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is depicted in Figure 1. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model are outlined in Table 1. This model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as shown in Figure 1: SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, displaying a human (SEIR, yellow shade) and pathogen (P, green shade) component.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In a study by Mwalili et al. BMC Res Notes in 2020, it was found that there are non-linear interactions between humans and the environment, and thorough simulation studies were conducted. The study involved formulating a mathematical model for the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. This model included two interacting populations: humans as hosts and pathogens. The human population at time t, denoted as N(t), was divided into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. The pathogen in the environment was denoted as P(t). The study revealed that the virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, were found to spread the virus to susceptible individuals with whom they had close contact. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking necessary precautions, the virus spreads to the environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Initial parameters such as baseline α and various levels of α (5, 10, 20) were used to analyze shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model. The susceptibility of individuals, infectious case dynamics, and the final state of the system were examined based on different levels of shielding. The study took into consideration transmission rates and recovery rates, with interactions in hospital settings needing to be considered in specific implementation scenarios with healthcare workers. Further details on epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2, as well as in the code available on GitHub. An outbreak simulation was seeded with a single exposed individual until reaching 0.1% total prevalence, after which a shielding strategy was implemented. The outbreak scenarios varied in transmission rates, with different R0 values for low and high transmission scenarios. Early estimates of from Wuhan are consistent with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of between 2.1 and 4.5 (ref. 30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as
post_context: and other measures were implemented. The results displayed in Figure 3 demonstrate the impact of shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, implementing shielding measures alone has the potential to reduce the overall burden of an epidemic, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, our model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, compared to 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). For a low-transmission scenario with the same population size, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, compared to 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite lower numbers in those age ranges, the majority of deaths occur in individuals aged 60 years and older, aligning with estimates from other COVID-19 models and outbreaks in Italy and India. While our simulation focuses on the effects of shielding alone, ongoing restrictions such as social distancing will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields, which combines identification and interaction rates of recovered individuals. Population-scale effects of shielding are influenced by various factors such as demographics, asymptomatic transmission rates, and immunity duration. Demographic distributions skewed towards older age groups may benefit more from shielding measures, even with fewer recovered individuals between the ages of 20 and 60.

original_post_context: and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 shows the results of comparing shielding interventions to the baseline outbreak. As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Fig. 2 illustrates the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model. Panel a shows how infectious cases change with different levels of shielding (α), while panel b demonstrates the final state of the system based on α. The parameters used are β = 0.25 (transmission rate 1/days) and γ = 0.1 (recovery rate 1/days), with individuals categorized as susceptible (S), infectious (I), or recovered (R). It is important to consider interactions with patients in hospital settings when implementing specific scenarios with healthcare workers. Detailed epidemiological parameters, age-specific risk, and population structure information can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2, as well as in the code (available on GitHub at https://github.com/WeitzGroup/covid_shield_immunity).

We adopted the baseline epidemiological parameters and seeded an outbreak with a single exposed individual until reaching 0.1% total prevalence (10,000 infected out of 10,000,000 population), at which point a shielding strategy is implemented. The transmission rates varied, with 1.33 and 2.33 in low- and high-transmission scenarios respectively. Early estimates from Japan are consistent with an R0 of between 2.1 and 4.5.30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in Japan that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in Japan from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context:
2:38 and other measures were implemented.

Figure 3 illustrates the impact of different shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of an epidemic by lowering both the total impact and the duration of the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 under a high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). For a population of the same size under a low-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths occur among individuals aged 60 and older, despite their lower representation in the population, which is consistent with prior COVID-19 models and data from outbreaks in Italy and Japan. Our analysis focuses solely on the impact of shielding, while ongoing measures like social distancing and shelter-in-place orders contribute further to reducing interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding is influenced by the identification and substitutability of potential shields (αRshields), which combines the identification and interaction rates of recovered individuals. Population-scale outcomes of shielding are influenced by demographic distributions, the prevalence of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a skewed distribution towards older individuals may see heightened benefits from shielding. Though there are fewer recovered individuals between the ages of 20 and 60, the potential benefits of shielding remain considerable.

As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In a study published in 2020, researchers modeled the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease, which has spread rapidly in China and to more than 30 countries in a short period of time, has unique features such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Jiangxi) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangxi excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Jiangxi (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan. This number decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Jiangxi by late March, in the rest of China by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, with 49,510 from Wuhan, 17,679 from Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 from other regions of China. It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should remain in place until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and until late March in Jiangxi. This model can also be valuable for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance to other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and numerous other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics including high infectivity during incubation, delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict the epidemic trend using daily data from China. This model can also offer insights for other countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling COVID-19 Epidemic Dynamics and Control Measures in Japan

Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

This study focuses on modeling the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The disease has unique features such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, a model predicts that COVID-19 will end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in Japan excluding Hubei by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities by early March 2020. It is estimated that a total of 80,511 individuals are infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of Japan excluding Hubei. These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. Recommendations suggest maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Hiroshima, and late March in Hubei. The model can be used to predict epidemic trends and guide response in other countries at high risk of outbreak like South Korea, China, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading and has unique characteristics that require specific modeling approaches for prediction and response.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Email Received by chenh@big.ac.cn on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Context: Over the past two months, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries. COVID-19 has unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the virus.

Method: We have developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and specifically incorporate the effects of intervention measures. This model is more appropriate for this analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model was used to assess the confirmed infection data on a daily basis in various regions including Hangzhou, Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), China (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in China. Our findings indicate that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R greater than 1. After January 30, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R less than 1, demonstrating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context:
are from Hangzhou, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some level of uncertainty. Our analysis indicates that stringent quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative recommendations for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran.

In the face of the rapidly spreading coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and several other countries in the past two months, it is crucial to note the unique characteristics of this disease, such as its high infectivity during the incubation period, the time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Chinese data to predict the epidemic trend. This model can also provide valuable insights for countries at risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Received February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and over 30 other countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. 
To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, we created a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model. This model explicitly considers the impact of control measures and is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models. 
Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions in China. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, most regions had a reproductive number R > 1, indicating rapid spread. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, highlighting the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the virus.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan).Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be understood with some level of uncertainty. Our recommendations suggest maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be utilized to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative advice for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and in over 30 countries worldwide. With unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures, a SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. By applying SUQC to the daily data from China, we can predict the epidemic trend and provide valuable guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Vietnam excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. This model can also offer valuable predictions for the epidemic trend and serve as a quantitative guide for other at-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
original_post_context: from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily numbers of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of quarantine and control measures. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. SUQC can also provide quantitative guidance for other countries in a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

Using inferred parameters, we created long-term predictions for total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U), quarantined infected (Q), and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Hangzhou (Figure 1A). The model predicts the end time to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analysis of stage I data from Hangzhou, assuming no strict quarantine measures, shows a significant increase in predicted C(t) and I(t) numbers, exceeding observed numbers after Jan 21 (Figure 1C, D).The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.

pre_context:
Analysis of the COVID-19 epidemic dynamics in Hunan province (excluding the quarantine center) involves predicting and testing with stage I and stage II data. In stage II, the quarantine center has a lower quarantine rate and a higher reproductive number compared to other regions, leading to a decrease in the reproductive number as the epidemic progresses. The presence of un-quarantined individuals contributes to new infections, with a high estimated number of un-quarantined individuals in the quarantine center on Feb 12 despite efforts to control the epidemic. Person-to-person transmission will last for more than two months to late May 2020. However, estimated with stage III data, the quarantine rate of the quarantine center increases to 0.6185, and the un-quarantined infected individuals decrease to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E).

The four major cities of Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Yokohama are expected to reach zero un-quarantined infections before early April. Typically, achieving zero un-quarantined infections occurs earlier than reaching zero new confirmed infections.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into consideration involves allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean determined by the assumed model and the variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be influenced by the mean. As we will show, a lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modelers. A crucial factor that contributes to the variation in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) aligns with the model's projections. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, were tested, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed through DNA or imaging tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, regardless of whether they exhibit symptoms, have been in contact with healthcare facilities, have confirmed test results, or have been misdiagnosed. Therefore, confirmed cases (data) represent only a portion of the total infected population (model predictions). A fitting analogy for this distinction is that of an iceberg, where the entire iceberg symbolizes the complete infected population, with the tip above the water representing the confirmed cases. The submerged portion of the iceberg signifies the infected individuals who are not detected through public health surveillance and testing, often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate important parameters like the transmission rate b, it is essential to adjust the model output by discounting the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), by the case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data. By trying out different values of r, a corresponding transmission rate b can be determined by matching the model to actual data, ultimately influencing the basic reproduction number R0, the size of the epidemic, and the peak timing. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b varies widely, leading to a broad spectrum of model predictions. This variability, known in the modeling literature as nonidentifiability, complicates the process of accurately determining model parameters based on available data. Different combinations of r and b may fit the data well but result in divergent predictions about the epidemic. How nonidentifiability is addressed during model calibration significantly impacts the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method may struggle with detecting or resolving this issue due to its basic optimization algorithm, which aims to find a global minimum of the objective function but may encounter many different equally valid minima.

The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

author: chunwei
pre_context: If the value of Di is less than 7, model i is considered to have less support. If Di is greater than 10, model i is considered to have no support and can be excluded. When dealing with a large number of models or models that are not nested, the rules for model selection differ. For more information on model selection, please refer to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E represents individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically plausible due to a potential incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not yet be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms such as fever and coughing. Unlike SARS, where individuals typically become infectious two days after symptom onset, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can be contagious before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the model's predictive period. The differential equations for each model are provided, and data calibration involves using newly confirmed case data to match the rI term in both models, rendering the death term in the R compartment irrelevant for model fitting.

original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.

In this discussion, we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of clinical symptoms such as fever and cough for COVID-19. In the case of SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence suggests that individuals can be infectious before symptoms appear, but the exact length of the latent period is unknown. The SEIR model is considered more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Diagrams for both models are provided in Figure 1, and the biological meanings of all model parameters are explained in Tables 1 and 2. Both models assume that deaths in the susceptible, exposed, and infectious compartments are negligible during the model prediction period. The differential equations for each model are shown below. Model calibration is based on newly confirmed cases in Location: Shanghai from January 21 to February 4, 2020, as reported by the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China.

author: enrique
pre_context: Data from technical, surveillance, or administrative sources, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens that occur in real-time, like SARS in 2003 and COVID-19. Another approach is to utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting process, employing Bayesian inference and an affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Baseline predictions for Shanghai and three scenarios were developed based on randomly sampling the posterior distribution to generate prediction intervals. The parameter values and intervals were derived using Bayesian inference with newly confirmed cases reported in Shanghai from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections offer insight into the potential trajectory of the epidemic in Shanghai if additional control measures implemented after February 7 had not been put in place. Figures 4(a) and 4(b) illustrate the distributions of projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Shanghai together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 25, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our estimates, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7th, the number of peak cases in Shanghai could reach around 120,000 and the epidemic would likely continue until mid-May 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.
original_post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. By our projection, without the strict quarantine measures after February 7, the peak case total would reach approximately 120; 000, and the epidemic in Wuhan would not be over before mid-May of 2020.

At the time of this manuscript, the consensus among medical experts is that the basic reproduction number R 0 near the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak in Shanghai is around 2. Our result in Fig. 4 (b) is comparable with earlier estimates and the current consensus. We then narrowed down the parameter r to three ranges: ð0:02; 0:03Þ, ð0:05; 0:1Þ, and ð0.2; 1Þ, and adjusted the SIR model accordingly. The resulting predictions for new confirmed cases are illustrated in Fig. 5, showing the time courses of the COVID-19 epidemic in Shanghai under different diagnosis rate ranges. Day 0 in the simulations corresponds to January 21, 2020.

pre_context: Figure 4 illustrates the estimated peak time and control reproduction number (Rc) for the COVID-19 epidemic in Zhengzhou following the lockdown. The dashed lines in the graph represent the 95% prediction intervals for the epidemic's time course after the lockdown. In our simulations, January 21, 2020 is considered as Day 0. Medical experts currently believe that the basic reproduction number (R0) at the start of the outbreak in Zhengzhou was around 2, which is consistent with our findings in Fig. 4 (b) and previous estimates. It also shows that, even without the more restrictive control measures in Zhengzhou undertaken after February 7, the lockdown and travel restrictions in the city had slowed down the transmission and reduced the basic reproduction number to a control reproduction number Rc with a mean value 1.629. We will estimate the impact of the more restrictive control measures in Section 6. The baseline prediction intervals are computed over a large credible interval of the diagnosis rate r, ð0:0637;0:909Þ, which represents a wide range of assumptions on the case-infection ratio and the scale of the epidemic in Zhengzhou. author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β is influenced by the type of contact when considering realistic network structures including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts. Default transmission probabilities for different contact types are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected to align with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types. When considering factors such as age-based susceptibility and number of contacts in each layer, transmission events are estimated to occur roughly 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community in an unmitigated scenario. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Additionally, individual infectiousness can vary based on disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals under default parameter values are depicted in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation; estimated proportions for Seattle can be found in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infected person does not show symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not lower, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted as necessary based on the modeling application or situation, acknowledging that some studies have suggested significantly lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25].
